content:
ASIA-PAC

China is seeking talks with the US over steel and aluminium tariffs and is to resort to the WTO to defend interests. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK Brexit negotiators are reportedly being urged to come up with a fresh proposal to break the deadlock regarding the Irish border amid ongoing discussions on the issue which are set to last several weeks. (Guardian)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Mar) 51.7 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.5). (Newswires)
 

EU

Italy’s President Mattarella said consultations have not made any sign of a coalition deal and noted that new consultations will take place next week. (Newswires)

Italy’s Five Star Movement leader Di Maio said that with their party in government, Italy will be allied with the EU, Monetary Union and NATO, while he also reiterated he proposes a Germany-style contract on coalition government with either the League or PD. (Newswires)

Italy's League leader Salvini said he has not ruled out any possible partners regarding a coalition and that given current numbers, a lasting government should include 5SM. (Newswires)

Italy’s League and 5SM are said to have narrowed policy differences according to the League’s economic advisor, while there were also comments from Italy’s Berlusconi who claimed that any government must be based on a centre-right coalition. (Newswires)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Mar) 54.9 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.0). (Newswires)
EU Markit Composite Final PMI (Mar) 55.2 vs. Exp. 55.3 (Prev. 55.3)

EU Retail Sales MM (Feb) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. -0.1%, Rev. -0.3%)
EU Retail Sales YY (Feb) 1.8% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.3%, Rev. 1.5%)

EU Producer Prices MM (Feb) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.4%)
EU Producer Prices YY (Feb) 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%, Rev. 1.6%)


FX

The USD strengthened against most of its major counterparts particularly GBP and JPY. Cable tumbled after the UK services PMI fell to an almost two-year low, which was partly linked to disruption from the Beast from the East vicious storm that had brought heavy snow. Elsewhere, JPY fell amid improving risk sentiment as equities rallied again, with USD/JPY rising back above 107.00. The TRY dropped to a record low against the USD, initially amid reports that Deputy PM Simsek was to resign, however, Simsek wrote on social media that he will work until his last breath to rebuild Turkey, quashing rumours that he’s set to quit.

SNB's Maechler said that the CHF is still considered a safe haven and that an expansive policy is still needed. (Newswires)

SNB's Moser said situation in currency market remains fragile, while he added that the SNB must stay alert and is ready to influence the currency market if needed. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures both closed in positive territory amid improving risk appetite and as Larry Kudlow played down fears of an all-out trade war. Oil prices were benefitting “as signs emerge that the trade dispute is easing between the U.S. and China," wrote Commerzbank. The broad USD strength did seem to cap gains in oil prices but overall news in the energy sector was relatively light, although the Qatar energy minister said that OPEC should maintain production cuts.


US

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said Fed should take a pause on hikes once the neutral rate is reached and that policy has a little way to go before reaching neutral rate, while he also commented that some asset markets are getting aggressively priced. (Newswires)

US President Trump said it's time we did something on trade with China, while he also stated it is possible we will have something soon on NAFTA but can cancel it if needed. (Newswires)

White House economic adviser Kudlow said that the US will get a trade deal with China "over a period of time", but added that barriers will come down on both sides. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed US at "AAA"; outlook stable. (Newswires)

US International Trade $ (Feb) -57.6B vs. Exp. -56.8B (Prev. -56.6B, Rev. -56.7B). (Newswires)
US Initial Jobless Claims (29 Mar) 242k vs. Exp. 225k (Prev. 215k, Rev. 218k)


MARKET RECAP

US equity indices carried on the climb from yesterday following further easing on trade war concerns as the tariffs seem to be more of a negotiating tactic, as well as China now seeking talks with the US. Following this, NEC Director Kudlow said the US will get a trade deal with China “over a period of time” and that barriers will come down on both sides. The tempered trade war concerns led to the basic material sector (+1.9%) outperforming with US Steel (X) up almost 5% at the end of Thursday trade; energy (+1.8%) also an outperformer today on the back of higher oil prices.

In terms of stock specific news, Thursday saw a slew of initiations from UBS on semiconductor names (AMD, AVGO, MU, NVDA) which seemed to slow the recovering tech sector with Micron the biggest underperformer in both the SPX & NDX, closing lower by 6%. Also, Citron Research posted cautious comments on NVDA saying it expects to see shares below USD 200, soon. On the positive side, Boeing (BA) recovered from yesterday’s losses closing highest in the DJI, and Navient (NAVI), todays largest gainer in the SPX following an upgrade at Compass Point, as well as Canyon Capital reporting a 7.8% stake with intentions to discuss potential board nominees. SPX +0.68% at 2662.62, NDX +0.53% at 6594.84, DJI +0.99% at 24503.40.

US treasuries declined on Thursday as stocks continued their push higher seen throughout the last two trading days. Focus was again on comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow who played down fears of a full-blown trade war for the second consecutive day, calling the tariffs on China a negotiating tool. Treasuries had been lower from the off, before catching an early bid amid a chunky block buy prior to the CME open. IFR noted that volume was notably light ahead of Friday’s Nonfarm Payrolls report. T-Note futures (June 2018) settled down 8+ ticks at 120-18.

content:
US MARKET WRAP

* SNAPSHOT: Stocks up, USD up, treasuries down, oil up
* REAR-VIEW: Equities maintain momentum as imminent trade war concerns dissipate for now
* AHEAD: US employment situation report, Canadian labour market report, Fed’s Powell

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.68% at 2662.62, NDX +0.53% at 6594.84, DJI +0.99% at 24503.40
* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.4%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.5%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.8%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.8%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.1%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +0.9%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.9%, TECH (XLK): +0.6%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.7%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.8%.
US equity indices carried on the climb from yesterday following further easing on trade war concerns as the tariffs seem to be more of a negotiating tactic, as well as China now seeking talks with the US. Following this, NEC Director Kudlow said the US will get a trade deal with China “over a period of time” and that barriers will come down on both sides. The tempered trade war concerns led to the basic material sector (+1.9%) outperforming with US Steel (X) up almost 5% at the end of Thursday trade; energy (+1.8%) also an outperformer today on the back of higher oil prices.
Stock specific news, Thursday saw a slew of initiations from UBS on semiconductor names (AMD, AVGO, MU, NVDA) which seemed to slow the recovering tech sector with Micron the biggest underperformer in both the SPX & NDX, closing lower by 6%. Also, Citron Research posted cautious comments on NVDA saying it expects to see shares below USD 200, soon. On the positive side, Boeing (BA) recovered from yesterday’s losses closing highest in the DJI, and Navient (NAVI), todays largest gainer in the SPX following an upgrade at Compass Point, as well as Canyon Capital reporting a 7.8% stake with intentions to discuss potential board nominees.

* TREASURIES: T-Note futures (June 2018) settled down 8+ ticks at 120-18
US treasuries declined on Thursday as stocks continued their push higher seen throughout the last two trading days. Focus was again on comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow who played down fears of a full blown trade war for the second consecutive day, calling the tariffs on China a negotiating tool. Treasuries had been lower from the off, before catching an early bid amid a chunky block buy prior to the CME open. IFR noted that volume was notably light ahead of Friday’s Nonfarm Payrolls report.

* FOREX: USD strength ahead of Friday’s NFP
The USD strengthened against most of its major counterparts particularly GBP and JPY. Cable tumbled after the UK services PMI tumbled to an almost two-year low, although this was partly linked to disruption from the Beast from the East, no not Vladimir Putin, but a vicious storm that brought heavy snow. The surveys indicated growth of below 0.3% for the quarter, down from the already sluggish 0.4% seen in Q4 2017. The JPY fell amid improving risk sentiment as equities rallied again, with USD/JPY rising back above 107.00. The TRY dropped to a record low against the USD, initially amid reports that Deputy PM Simsek was to resign, however, Simsek wrote on social media that he will work until his last breath to rebuild Turkey, quashing rumours that he’s set to quit.

* CRUDE: WTI futures (May) settle 17 cents higher at $63.54; Brent futures (June) settle 31 cents higher at $68.33
WTI and Brent crude futures both closed in positive territory amid improving risk appetite and as Larry Kudlow played down fears of an all out trade war. Oil prices were benefitting “as signs emerge that the trade dispute is easing between the U.S. and China," wrote Commerzbank. The broad USD strength did seem to cap gains in oil prices but overall news in the energy sector was relatively light, although the Qatar energy minister said that OPEC should maintain production cuts.

Daily FX Wrap: trade tensions dissipate, but trade deficits deteriorate
content:
DXY

Broad Dollar gains on more conciliatory US-China import tariff developments extended alongside improving risk sentiment during Wednesday’s session, but the Index stalled just before 90.500 in wake of disappointing US data, including February’s trade balance, although the deficit between the 2 nations actually closed marginally, and weekly jobless claims (latter ahead of Friday’s NFP release).

CAD

The Loonie recovered from its own trade data downturn with the aid of more bullish reports on NAFTA negotiations with Canadian OM Trudeau claiming ‘significant’ progress – Usd/Cad backed off from another test of 1.2800 to sit midway between the big figure and a 1.2745 low.

GBP

The Pound was unable to withstand the Greenback revival or a 2nd big UK PMI miss (and this time in services), with Cable down to 1.4000 at worst vs virtually 1.4100 at one stage.

EUR

Eventually triggered sell-orders at 1.2250 and briefly breached the first band of buying interest within a major chart downside band from 1.2240-20 before the aforementioned loss of Usd momentum. However, the single currency outperformed Sterling with the cross firmer in a 0.8745-15 approximate band.

JPY/CHF

The renowned currency safe-havens both lost ground to the Usd, but the former more so around 107.25 and extending the top of recent ranges, with offers at 107.30 protecting stops at the 55 DMA (107.33). The Franc slipped to almost 0.9640, but held up better on above forecast Swiss CPI data.

AUD/NZD

Similar divergence or relative performance down under as macro supply in the cross kept the Aud pressured (along with 0.7700+ resistance vs the Usd) and the Kiwi afloat (around 1.0560 and 0.7275 respctively).

content: Broadly weaker than expected US data has helped debt futures consolidate off worst levels, and US Treasuries also saw decent block buying (circa 12.5k lots in 10s at 120-21) ahead of the raft of releases, but it’s still risk-back-on overall with stocks elevated near intraday peaks in the run up to the Wall St open and perhaps heading higher after latest comments from new White House economic advisor Kudlow who believes a trade accord with China is achievable. However, the Usd has faded somewhat after tripping more stops in Eur/Usd at 1.2250 and briefly probing below chart support at 1.2240, while Cable got within a whisker of 1.4000 and Usd/Jpy as close to its 107.15 high. Conversely, Usd/Cad remains near 1.2800 with the Loonie also feeling the weight of a larger than forecast trade shortfall.

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - Earnings from Monsanto (MON)
content:
5th April 2018

EARNINGS

  • RPM (RPM) – Q3 EPS USD 0.30 including tax benefit vs Exp. USD 0.18, revenue USD 1.1bln vs Exp. USD 1.1bln. Narrowed its FY18 EPS forecast. (Newswires)
  • Conn’s (CONN) – Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.56 vs Exp. USD 0.54, revenue USD 420.39mln vs Exp. USD 428.69mln. SSS -8%. (Newswires)
  • Monsanto (MON) - Q2 ongoing EPS 3.22 vs Exp. USD 3.38, Revenue USD 5.02bln vs Exp. USD 5.49bln. Notes solid progress in Bayer regulatory process. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • General Electric (GE) – The co. said it plans to provide restated 2016 & 2017 results before April 13th to reflect a new accounting standard which considers revenue from long term contracts which are being scrutinised by the SEC, its earnings report on April 20th will be under the new standard. (Newswires)
  • JP Morgan (JPM) / Black Knight (BKI) – JP Morgan has announced it has signed a contract to implement Black Knights Loan Sphere Empower loan origination system to support its home equity originations business. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – The sports apparel co. HR Chief has said it has failed to promote enough women and minorities. (WSJ)

S&P500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) / Biogen (BIIB) - AbbVie announced a global resolution of all intellectual property related litigation with Samsung Bioepis over Humira patent disputes, Biogen and Samsung Bioepis also reached an agreement with AbbVie for the commercialisation of Imraldi. (Newswires)
  • Bank Names (JPM, WFC, MS, GS) – President of UBS’s (UBSG SW) Investment bank has said he has a very aggressive plan for the US. (Newswires)
  • CBS (CBS) / Viacom (VIAB) – The merger discussions between the two are facing a wall over disputes on leadership and pricing. (WSJ)
  • Delta (DAL) – The airline announced that some of its customers payment data has been breached. (NY Post)
  • Equifax (EFX) – A judge has ruled that Massachusetts can go ahead and sue the co. over the recent data breach. (Newswires)
  • Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) – The co. has set a regular cash dividend of USD 0.1125/shr. (Newswires)
  • InterContinental Exchange (ICE) – The co. announced it has agreed to acquire Chicago Stock Exchange; financial terms not disclosed. (Newswires)
  • J M Smucker (SJM) – The co. is to acquire Ainsworth Pet Nutrition in a USD 1.7bln purchase, excluding an estimated tax benefit of USD 200Mln. Further, it is also looking at alternatives for its baking business, which includes Pillsbury and Martha White brands. (Newswires / CNBC)
  • L3 Technologies (LLL) – The co.’s Vertex Aerospace is part of a USD 25.5bln consortium for aircraft and support equipment maintenance. (Newswires)
  • Macy’s (M) – The retailer CFO Karen Houget will retire next February if a successor is appointed. (Newswires)
  • Navient (NAVI) – Canyon Capital has reported a 7.8% stake in the co., this comes after John Adams announced he will not stand for re-election, Canyon are intending to discuss potential nominees with the current board members. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Align Tech. (ALGN) – The co. is extending the Invisalign product family with Invisalign first clear aligners. (Newswires)
  • Adobe (ADBE) – The co. has appointed John Murphy as CFO, effective April 9th. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – Morgan Stanley note on the the retail giant says its potential sales tax increases remain uncertain and are potentially somewhat mitigated and sees a fair negotiation between the co. and US Postal Service as a mutually beneficial relationship. Separately, reports in WSJ suggest the co. is expected to grow its government business, despite recent attacks from US President Trump. (Morgan Stanley / WSJ)
  • Broadcom (AVGO) – The co. has completed its redomiciliation process back to the US. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – Cambridge Analytica denied reports from Facebook saying up to 87mln customers may have been affected, saying they only obtained data for no more than 30mln. Separately, Zuckerberg has said he is the “best man for the job” and that he was “too flippant” about Russian meddling. (Recode / Newswires)
  • Liberty Global (LBTYA) – The co. has asked the EU antitrust regulators to approve its takeover of Dutch peer Ziggo, a deadline of May 15th has been set. (Newswires)
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) – The drug retailer supports the importance of Naloxone to be easier accessible to those who need to prevent opioid related deaths. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Conatus Pharmaceuticals (CNAT) - Phase 2b POLT-HCV-SVR proof-of-concept clinical trial of liver transplant patients misses primary endpoint. (Newswires)
  • Carlyle Group (CG) – The co. will purchase Australia’s Accolade Wines from a PE firm for AUD 1bln (USD 770mln), triple for what the PE firm bought it for seven years ago. (Newswires)
  • Sandridge (SD) – Carl Icahn is intending to nominate a full slate of candidates the co. board. (Newswires)
  • Match (MTCH) – Changes to Facebook’s (FB) login are forcing the Tinder app to go down. (Independent)
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) – The automaker is to spin off its parts unit, Magneti Marelli. Co. expects spin-off to be completed by the end of 2018 or start of 2019. (Newswires)
  • Sears (SHLD) – The co. may have had some of its customer payment information exposed in a security hack. (Newswires)
  • GMS (GMS) – The co. announced a definitive agreement to acquire WSB Titan for USD 627mln. (Newswires)
  • TiVo (TIVO) – The co. may attract interest from the tech giants such as Alphabet’s (GOOG) Google, Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL). (The Street)
  • Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) – Kimmeridge has increased its stake in the co. and is urging the sale of assets or a merger. (WSJ)

  • AMD (AMD) upgraded to Buy from Hold at Stifel
  • ArQule (ARQL) upgraded to Outperform from Market Perform at Leerink
  • AutoZone (AZO) upgraded to Outperform from Neutral at Wedbush
  • Cadence Design (CDNS) upgraded to Buy from Neutral at DA Davidson
  • CarMax (KMX) upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Buckingham
  • Cinemark (CNK) upgraded to Neutral from Sell at MoffettNathanson
  • Citigroup (C) upgraded to buy from Neutral at UBS

subject: EU-MID SESSION UPDATE: European bourses bounce back with vengeance
content:
EQUITIES

European bourses opened higher with 88% of the Stoxx 600 in the green as it sustained the momentum and risk appetite from Wall St. and Asia. The improvement in sentiment was aided by comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow stating that the US measures were a form of trade negotiations and that Trump’s tariffs on China are all proposals, while he added that back-channel talks with China were occurring. All sectors sit firmly in the green with material and technology names top-performers. Financials are also higher as banks benefit from the US 10y yield rising back above 2.80%. In terms of stock specifics, Telecom Italia (+3.0%) is higher on sources reporting Italian state lender CDP is to purchase a 5% stake in the company. Lagging behind, Just Eat (-3.3%) is failing to deliver on the back of a downgrade by JP Morgan.

FX

DXY

The Index looks a bit more comfortable back above the psychological 90.000 level and with the Greenback firmer vs all G10 peers, bar the Loonie that continues to glean encouragement from broadly constructive NAFTA developments (negotiations said to be progressing well, albeit with some major issues yet to be resolved, and on track for an agreement in principle by mid-April). A truce or rather a time out for talks between the US and China on proposed import tariffs has calmed trade war fears, underpinning the Dollar and risk sentiment in general to the detriment of traditional safe-havens. However, the DXY really needs to reclaim 90.500 and above to maintain momentum vs highs around 90.335 thus far.

CAD

Bucking the broader trend due to the aforementioned positive NAFTA impulses and back near recent peaks vs the Usd within 1.2780-45 parameters ahead of Canadian (and US) trade data.

CHF

Also a bit of an outlier among majors with firmer than forecast Swiss CPI data supporting the Franc between 0.9600-30 and 1.1790-1.1805 vs the Usd and Eur respectively, but the Chf still not really trading like a safe-haven amidst market talk of SNB intervention.

GBP

Another mover on independent factors, or to be precise in the run up to a much weaker than expected UK services PMI, with Cable drifting back from yet another test of 1.4100 resistance/multiple tops to around 1.4035 and Eur/Gbp nudging towards 0.8740.

EUR

Losing more ground from recent 1.2300+ peaks vs the Usd and seriously probing stops around 1.2250 ahead of more layered bids in the 1.2240-20 area and decent tech support at the upper end of that range.

JPY

Also extending losses vs the Usd and the headline pair probing a bit higher above 107.00, but not quite challenging offers said to be sitting at 107.20 and 107.30, which could expose stops above the 107.33 level (55 DMA).

AUD/NZD

Somewhat contrasting fortunes for the Antipodean units continue with market observers noting macro offers in the cross, which remains around 1.0550 or just below, while the Aud has been unable to derive support from data again and recoils from another 0.7700+ venture, as better than consensus trade data was tainted by a downgrade to the previous month and weak internals.

FIXED INCOME

Only fleeting respite for Gilts in wake of another significant UK PMI miss, and this time from the key services sector, as the Beast from the East appears to have wreaked havoc in keeping with the destruction caused in construction activity. Hence, discounting the weather UK debt has quickly returned to trading off broader risk sentiment and alongside core bond peers are conceding more ground amidst heavy supply from the Eurozone. The 10 year UK benchmark has now been down to 122.14, -56 ticks on the day, with Bunds as low as 158.95, -52 ticks, and US Treasuries are seeing more pronounced/deeper bear steepening. Note, aside from a pretty full US agenda ahead of Friday’s big NFP release, next week’s auction amounts are also due to be announced.  

COMMODITIES

Oil prices have extended their post-DoE gains (May ’18 crude WTI futures hovering around USD 63.50/bbl) amid the easing of trade war fears after US officials said they are open to negotiations with China over tariffs. Gold has lost support from safe-haven flows with prices pulling back from one-week highs as the risk tone returns to the market. Copper traded sideways during Asia hours with its largest consumer China shut for the rest of the week due to holidays, while improved market sentiment lifted London copper, which has recouped the losses seen in the previous session. Elsewhere, Shanghai aluminium stocks tumbled for the first time in nine months.

subject: PREVIEW: RBI unanimously expected to keep rates unchanged in policy announcement due later at 1000BST/0400CDT/1700HKT
content:
The RBI is to conclude its first bi-monthly policy meeting for the 2018-2019 fiscal year later, where the central bank is expected to stand pat with all economists surveyed unanimously anticipating the central bank to maintain the Repurchase Rate at 6.00%, Reverse Repo Rate at 5.75% and Cash Reserve Ratio at 4.00%.

Despite the one-sided expectations for today’s announcement, forecasts are less clear-cut for what the central bank may do throughout the financial year as one survey showed 6 out of 15 economists expect a hike, 2 were calling for a cut, 4 forecast a prolonged pause by the RBI and 3 anticipate the RBI to be data dependent. Furthermore, a separate larger poll suggested 60% were predicting the central bank to shift to a policy tightening stance by year-end and that the consensus was for a 25bps hike during Q1 2019 vs. Prev. forecast for a first hike during H2 2019.

The recent data releases from India hints to a lack of urgency to adjust policy rates as India CPI for February eased to 4.4% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 5.1%) and although this effectively increases the scope for rate cuts, stronger Industrial Production growth at 7.5% vs. Exp. 6.4% (Prev. 7.1%) would suggest that looser policy is currently unwarranted. Furthermore, the backdrop of policy normalization or intentions thereof, amongst some of the major global central banks would also be a hindrance for the RBI to lower rates.

A recent notable development which has been the centre of focus in India was the bank loan fraud in which the country’s 2nd biggest lender Punjab National Bank discovered the largest loan fraud in the nation’s history. This resulted to the RBI banning the use of Letters of Undertaking and Letters of Comfort as trade credits for imports, which in turn raised concerns for businesses and that importers’ costs would increase as they would now need more USD for payments to overseas suppliers which would also pressure INR. Therefore, the uncertainty following the ban of these guarantees would be another factor likely to persuade the RBI to maintain a wait-and-see approach in the near-term.

Another fall-out of the banking fraud scandal, was the differences between the government and RBI regarding regulatory powers over public sector banks in which the government dismissed calls by the central bank for increased authority over the nation’s banking sector. This refusal by the government to the RBI’s request may somewhat place a dampener on their relationship and could in turn lessen the RBI’s susceptibility to conform next time the government pressures again for rate cuts.

Today’s decision is due out at 10:00BST and as forecasts are one-sided for no changes in rates, focus will turn to the accompanying statement for any hints on the central bank’s thinking and whether there is any shift from its current neutral stance. As a reminder, the impact to INR from RBI announcements are not so straight-forward as dovish surprises have in the past underpinned the currency instead of weakening it, which is due to the suspected inflows of funds on the back of more favourable policies.

subject: Short Sterling strip stirred, Gilts endure a shaky start
content: UK rates rattled by the latest twist in broad risk sentiment and a significant switch from aversion on reduced global trade war concerns as the US and China enter negotiations after setting their respective stalls out on import tariffs. 3 month STIR futures are unwinding or reversing some of their recent bull-flattening and accordingly this could curb the steep rise in Libor seen of late. Meanwhile, Gilts have resumed Liffe under pressure in line with safe-haven debt counterparts and extending losses from an initial 122.49 print to 122.32 (-38 ticks), as Bunds also succumb to more selling pressure and retreat further towards this week’s lows and the 159.00 level at 159.10 (-37 ticks). Looking ahead, UK debt and STIRs await the services PMI for some independent impetus.

subject: Bunds: on the back foot again amidst resurgent risk appetite
content: All change again for the 10 year German benchmark and counterpart core bonds as Wall Street staged another impressive recovery rally on a marked swing in sentiment surrounding the US-China trade spat after both sides sought to soothe fears over extensive import tariff lists. In short, the proposals are statements of intent and designed to form the basis of talks that are already underway behind closed doors, so there is room for negotiation before any implementation. As usual, Bunds have largely shrugged off German factory orders that are relatively old in terms of a reference point given more timely economic indicators already released (ie final March manufacturing PMIs), and following an initial markdown to 159.22 from Wednesday’s 159.47 Eurex close price action has continued mostly on the downside within a 159.15-25 range. Ahead, services PMIs may offer some macro impetus along with Eurozone PPI, but for debt markets hefty Spanish and French supply is far more likely to impact via pre-auction hedging and unwinding after the results.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where all major indices recovered from the initial losses seen after US and China’s tit-for-tat tariff announcements, with fears later soothed as the US hinted at a willingness for negotiations. The improvement in sentiment was helped by comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow who stated that the US measures were a form of trade negotiations and that Trump’s tariffs on China are all proposals, while he added that back-channel talks with China were occurring. Furthermore, the White House noted there will be a couple of months before China tariffs are implemented with the review period ongoing, and some analysts also viewed the impact from proposed tariffs to be manageable. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) were higher with strength in Australia’s largest weighted financials sector leading the local index, and the Japanese benchmark was among the outperformers as exporters cheered a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, KOSPI (+1.6%) also advanced and Straits Times Index (+1.8%) saw its largest intraday gain in over a year alongside the rising tide across stocks, while mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan remained shut for holidays.

Separately, the co. has settled a lawsuit against its former JWT head Gustavo Martinez, terms are confidential and have not been disclosed. (The Telegraph/Business Insider)

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.58%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +1.66%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.02%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.02%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +1.44%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +0.26%, MATERIALS (XLB): +0.57%, TECH (XLK): +1.20%, TELECOMS (XTL): +1.17%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.19%.

US Equity futures started trade on Wednesday deeply in the red; trade war uncertainties hit Wall St. after China retaliated against US tariffs with their own reciprocal measures, which led to a decline in industrial names such as Boeing (BA) and Deere (DE). However, as trade progressed, markets seemed to shake-off the tariff concerns, paring back losses and closing higher. Comments from NEC Director Kudlow helped, after he stated that the US measures were a form of trade negotiations, and back-channel talks with China were occurring; analysts, have also noted that the impact of the initially announced tariffs seems manageable, and perhaps markets have over reacted; the fear arises from any escalation which could lead to further more destructive measures. In M&A news CNBC’s Faber reported CBS (CBS) offered Viacom (VIAB) USD 0.55/shr and that Viacom immediately rejected the offer. Sources later reported that VIAB is preparing a counter-proposal by asking for over USD 0.62/shr. Elsewhere in tech, sentiment around Amazon (AMZN) was further buoyed on Wednesday after White House officials told CNBC that there are almost certainly no specific policy actions going from the White House which target AMZN. Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) reported that the recently reported data leak hit 87mln users – it had previously said it was around 50mln users.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where all major indices staged a recovery
content:
• Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where all major indices staged a recovery
  • Sentiment was supported by comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow who stated that the US measures were a form of trade negotiations and that Trump’s tariffs on China are all proposals
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ and UK services PMI, US international trade, RBI rate decision

 

TRADE TARIFFS

US trade official said the US does not have a firm deadline for a final tariff list against China and that there may continue to be talks over trade with China, while the official refused to comment on specific action. (Newswires)

White House said there will be a couple of months before China tariffs are implemented, while it noted the review period is ongoing and if China does not make changes, the US will go ahead with their tariffs. In related news, the White House also said there is no new big trade initiative directed at China planned at this time which has not already been announced but said new actions could come in time. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow thinks China will "back down" and "play ball" regarding trade. Furthermore, Kudlow also added that President Trump's tariffs on China are all proposals. Furthermore, Kudlow had earlier suggested that US measures could be a form of trade negotiation tactics and that back-channel talks with China were occurring. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where all major indices recovered from the initial losses seen after US and China’s tit-for-tat tariff announcements, with fears later soothed as the US hinted at a willingness for negotiations. The improvement in sentiment was helped by comments from White House economic adviser Kudlow who stated that the US measures were a form of trade negotiations and that Trump’s tariffs on China are all proposals, while he added that back-channel talks with China were occurring. Furthermore, the White House noted there will be a couple of months before China tariffs are implemented with the review period ongoing, and some analysts also viewed the impact from proposed tariffs to be manageable. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) were higher with strength in Australia’s largest weighted financials sector leading the local index, and the Japanese benchmark was among the outperformers as exporters cheered a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, KOSPI (+1.6%) also advanced and Straits Times Index (+1.8%) saw its largest intraday gain in over a year alongside the rising tide across stocks, while mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan remained shut for holidays. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued following losses in T-notes and with safe-havens shunned amid the heightened risk appetite, while an enhanced-liquidity auction in the super-long end also kept participants side-lined during early trade and after results showed weaker demand.

UK/EU

UK Security services believe that they have pinpointed the location of the covert Russian laboratory that manufactured the weapons-grade nerve agent used in Salisbury. (Times)


FX

USD/JPY and JPY-crosses extended on their upside amid the heightened-risk appetite in which the pair eyed the 107.00 level to the upside, while CHF was also subdued by the safe-haven outflows with USD/CHF above the 0.9600 handle. Elsewhere, the other majors traded range-bound amid a flat greenback and several holiday closures, while AUD/USD pulled back and failed to benefit from a wider than expected trade surplus as the data also showed a downward revision to the prior and that exports flattened.

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Feb) 825M vs. Exp. 725M (Prev. 1,055M, Rev. 952M). (Newswires)
Australian Exports (Feb) M/M 0.0% (Prev. 4.0%)
Australian Imports (Feb) M/M 0.0% (Prev. -2.0%)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude future marginally extending on its post-DOE rebound in which an unexpected drawdown to headline crude stockpiles underpinned prices back above USD 66/bbl and with prices also propped up amid the improvement in risk sentiment. Conversely, gold loss some shine and weakened on safe-haven outflows, while copper traded sideways during Asia hours with its largest consumer China shut for the rest of the week due to holidays.

SocGen said it sees a 70% chance of Iran oil sanctions coming back into effect by May 12th which would remove 500K bpd of Iranian crude supply from the market. SocGen added that sanctions will take 2-3 months for implementation and sees a price impact of USD 10/bbl, of which half is already priced in. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US plans to sanction Russian oligarchs this week as it targets Moscow for alleged election meddling. (Newswires)
 

US

There was modest bear-steepening along the Treasury curve, after the pre-market risk-averse sentiment was shaken-off. Again, block trades in TYM8 helped some of the selling bias, as yesterday. Decent ADP employment data (beat expectations, prior revised up) has raised hopes of a stellar NFP report on Friday, seeing Tsys back-off highs, though analysts offered the usual caution about reading too much into the ADP data as a guide for the official NFP data. Additionally, risk sentiment was stoked in the US morning after constructive comments by US NEC Director Kudlow, where he intimated that the US and Chinese were in discussions over trade, and the market shouldn’t over-react to the initial, small steps taken to fight against China’s alleged theft of US intellectual property. T-Note futures (June 2018) settled half a tick lower at 120-26+.

US President Trump signed order to deploy the National Guard to its southern border, while there were earlier reports that Mexico Senate rejected US President Trump's border militarization plan and asked the government to halt migration cooperation with the US. (Newswires)

There were reports that President was said to soften NAFTA autos proposal and lower 85% demand on some auto parts, while White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said that NAFTA negotiations are proceeding rather well. (Newswires)

NAFTA negotiators are said to be reviewing alternatives on origin rules for autos, with US officials showing a more flexible approach to the issue according to sources. In related news, Canadian NAFTA negotiators are said to be open to US ideas on agreeing on a deal but are skeptical on completing the remaining chapters in the next 2 weeks as big gaps remain. However, they think a symbolic agreement in principle showing consensus on some important issues is possible, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Ambassador to Canada Craft said they have every confidence that US and Canada will fix NAFTA, while Canada Ambassador to the US MacNaughton, said 'a lot of issues' remain on NAFTA but noted that he is pleased with the positive tone of discussions. (Newswires)
